binsNotVisibleDescription: Bins not visible at current map scale and style changes cannot be made. Change map scale or click Back and adjust scale threshold.
clustersNotVisibleDescription: Clusters not visible at current map scale and style changes cannot be made. Change map scale or click Back and adjust scale threshold.

gallery.styleWithAIMsg: Have AI suggest attributes and styles
gallery.chooseAttributesMsg: Choose which fields you want to map. The order will affect how some styles are applied.
gallery.chooseAttributesMsgWithTips: To start smart mapping, choose which fields you want to map. The number and order of fields will affect how some styles are applied.
gallery.tip2: Add more fields to try more styles.

styleMsg.empty: Choose attributes above for more styles.
styleMsg.oneNumber: These styles are good for visualizing a single numeric field.
styleMsg.multipleNumber: These styles are good for visualizing multiple numeric fields.
styleMsg.any: These styles are good for your current field selection.

errors.getHistogramErrorMsg: The layer is not providing enough information to draw the histogram.

chart.groupingInfo: Values below the grouping % are aggregated into ${other} to simplify the chart.
chart.changeTooltip: Change the attribute and drawing style.
chart.otherTooltip: Show or hide features in this category.

vectorField.invertSymbolsTip:
Draw the symbols in the opposite direction.
By default, the symbols are displayed in the direction defined by the data. If the angle direction in the data is measured based on the beginning of the mass flow, such as wind, use this option to invert the vector symbol direction.

simpleScalar.title: Simple scalar
simpleScalar.description: Symbolizes the magnitude of the data using graduated symbol sizes.

singleArrow.title: Single arrow
singleArrow.description: A single arrow depicting direction and magnitude.

windBarbs.title: Wind barbs
windBarbs.description: Wind barbs indicating wind direction and magnitude.

beaufort.title: Beaufort wind scale
beaufort.description: Symbolizes the magnitude and direction of wind using the Beaufort Wind Scale.

oceanCurrentKnots.title: Ocean current (knots)
oceanCurrentKnots.description: Ocean current symbol indicating current and magnitude using 9 predefined categories.

oceanCurrentMps.title: Ocean current (m/s)
oceanCurrentMps.description: Ocean current symbol indicating current and magnitude using 4 predefined categories.

classifiedArrow.title: Classified arrow
classifiedArrow.description: Symbolizes the magnitude and direction of flow, using categories calculated based on magnitude limits.

hillshadeTypeOptionDescriptions.traditional: Calculates hillshade from a single illumination direction.
hillshadeTypeOptionDescriptions.multidirectional: Combines light from multiple sources to represent an enhanced visualization of the terrain.

heatmap.lockHelp: Prevents heat map from regenerating at each zoom level.

errors.tooManyValues: There are more than ${count} unique values. Values not listed here will still display on the map in this category.
errors.noFeatures: The selected attribute has no values. All features will draw as "${other}".

arcade.timeSeriesDescription: Create an animation from sequential temporal fields.

tooltips.title: When to use ${title}
tooltips.color: Use colors to represent your numeric or ranked data. Choose a theme that matches your data to a particular color scheme. For example, show data like age or income with the High-to-low theme that uses a simple light to dark color scheme.
tooltips.colorDate: Use colors to represent your date data. Choose a theme that matches your data to a particular color scheme. For example, show data like age or income with the Above and Below theme that centers the ramp on a meaningful value such as an average or a goal.
tooltips.colorAge: Use colors to represent the age of features. Age reflects the length of time from a start date to an end date. For example, show features less than 30 days old as green and more than 90 days old as red.
tooltips.size: Use different symbol sizes to represent your numeric or ranked data. The larger the symbol, the bigger the data value.
tooltips.sizeDate: Use different symbol sizes to represent your date data. For example, larger symbols could represent newer dates.
tooltips.sizeAge: Use size to represent the age of features. Age reflects the length of time from a start date to an end date. For example, show data like new crimes with a large symbol and have the symbol decrease in size until it is 90 days old.
tooltips.type: Show different categories of features — such as type of tree, road class, or province name — with different colors. Some categories will not have an inherent order. For categories that do, such as educational attainment and income, consider using a sequential color ramp to visualize ranked categories.
tooltips.typeDate: Show different categories of features — such as years or days — with different colors.
tooltips.color_Size: The first attribute you choose uses color to represent your numeric or ranked data. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your numeric or ranked data. This map style works particularly well when the first attribute is a rate, ratio, percent, index or similar type of data.
tooltips.color_SizeDate: The first attribute you choose uses color to represent your numeric or ranked data. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your date data as a continuous timeline.
tooltips.color_SizeAge: The first attribute you choose uses color to represent your numeric or ranked data. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent the age of features.
tooltips.colorDate_Size: The first attribute you choose uses color to represent your date data as a continuous timeline. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your numeric or ranked data.
tooltips.colorDate_SizeDate: The first attribute you choose uses color to represent your date data as a continuous timeline. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your date data as a continuous timeline.
tooltips.colorDate_SizeAge: The first attribute you choose uses color to represent your date data as a continuous timeline. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent the age of features.
tooltips.colorAge_Size: The first attribute you choose uses color to represent the age of features. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your numeric or ranked data.
tooltips.colorAge_SizeDate: The first attribute you choose uses color to represent the age of features. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your date data as a continuous timeline.
tooltips.type_Size: The first attribute you choose categorizes your data based on the unique values found, and uses color to distinguish them on the map. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your numeric or ranked data.
tooltips.type_SizeDate: The first attribute you choose categorizes your data based on the unique values found, and uses color to distinguish them on the map. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your date data as a continuous timeline.
tooltips.typeDate_Size: The first attribute you choose categorizes your date data based on the unique values found, and uses color to distinguish them on the map. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent your data.
tooltips.type_SizeAge: The first attribute you choose categorizes your data based on the unique values found, and uses color to distinguish them on the map. The second attribute uses different symbol sizes to represent the age of features.
tooltips.predominance: Compare attributes that share a common subject and unit of measurement to see which has the highest value. Example: choose Corn Acres, Wheat Acres, and Cotton Acres to see which is the predominant crop in each area. Color shows the predominant category and transparency shows the relative strength of the predominance.
tooltips.predominanceSize: Compare attributes that share a common subject and unit of measurement to see which has the highest value. Example: choose Corn Acres, Wheat Acres, and Cotton Acres to see which is the predominant crop in each area. Color shows the predominant category, size shows the sum of the categories, and transparency shows the relative strength of the predominance.
tooltips.sizeForPredominance: Use different symbol sizes to represent the sum of all categories. The larger the symbol, the bigger the value.
tooltips.chart: Compare the relative abundance of different categories of things at locations. Example: compare the relative proportions of different age generations in a country or state (gen-z, millenials, gen-x, and boomers).
tooltips.chartSize: Compare the relative abundance of different categories of things at locations and use size to capture the total amount or magnitude. Example: compare the relative proportions of different crop types (corn, wheat, soy beans, cotton) while the overall size of the pie depicts how much total crops are harvested.
tooltips.relationship: Use hybrid colors to view the relationship between two numeric attributes. Each attribute uses a distinct sequential color scheme to represent its classified data. Both schemes converge, allowing you to view and explore where the attributes may be related.
tooltips.relationshipSize: Use hybrid colors to view the relationship between the first two numeric attributes. The third attribute uses different sizes to represent your numeric or ranked data.
tooltips.location: Show the geographic boundaries, lines, or point locations of your data.
tooltips.dotDensity: Use dot density to visualize the distribution of one attribute or compare multiple attributes. Choose the quantity that each dot represents. Example: 1 dot represents 1,000 people or 1 dot represents 20 trees.
tooltips.heatMap: Show areas of high activity with stronger colors that appear to glow hotter.
tooltips.compare: The first attribute is compared to the second attribute, and represented as a simple ratio, or as "A as a percent of B", or as "A as a percent of A+B." Examples: Revenue / Cost of Sale, or Corn Acres / Total Acres, or Corn Acres / (Corn + Wheat Acres).
tooltips.stretch: Use a stretch renderer to enhance the visual contrast of data for analysis. An appropriate stretch renderer can enhance the contrast of imagery, allowing the user to control how their data is displayed for efficient imagery analysis.
tooltips.rgb: An RGB renderer is used to adjust the color bands of a multispectral image. Apply an RGB renderer to a layer to enhance feature visibility.
tooltips.classify: The Classify renderer displays thematic data by grouping cell values into classes. Use this type of thematic classification on continuous phenomena, such as slope, distance, or suitability, where you want to classify the range into a small number of classes and assign colors to those classes.
tooltips.uniqueValues: The Unique Values renderer is used to display each value in the image layer individually. For instance, you might have discrete categories representing particular objects on the earth's surface, such as those in a thematic layer, which could display soil types or land use.
tooltips.shadedRelief: Shaded relief renderer produces a grayscale or colored 3D representation of the surface on a layer, with the sun's relative position taken into account for shading the image. This renderer uses a hillshading technique for visualizing terrain determined by a light source and the slope and aspect of the elevation surface.
tooltips.vectorField: Use Vector field renderer to visualize flow direction and magnitude information in your raster with vector symbols.
tooltips.colormap: A colormap renderer displays single-band thematic data based on specific colors, aiding in visual analysis of the data. Like the unique values renderer, the colormap renderer should be used to differentiate between classes or categories, but with a set of predefined colors from the associated colormap.
tooltips.flow: Motion helps to highlight both the direction and magnitude of flow in a field. Apply blend modes or layer effects to further enhance the lines.

transparency.transparencyLabel: Set transparency based on attribute values
transparency.transparencyLabelPredominance: Set transparency based on the predominant percentage

color.highToLowMsg: Vary the color of features from high to low.
color.aboveAndBelowMsg: Show data above and below a value like zero or the average.
color.centeredMsg: Center on and highlight a particular range of values.
color.aboveMsg: Emphasize data above a key value like zero or the average.
color.belowMsg: Emphasize data below a key value like zero or the average.
color.newToOldMsg: Vary the color of features from new to old.
color.beforeAndAfterMsg: Show dates before and after a given date.
color.beforeMsg: Emphasize data before a key date.
color.afterMsg: Emphasize data after a key date.

size.highToLowMsg: Vary the size of features from high to low.
size.aboveMsg: Emphasize data above a key value like zero or the average.
size.belowMsg: Emphasize data below a key value like zero or the average.
size.referenceSizeMsg: Vary the size of features from high to low with a bounding outline for reference.
size.spikeMsg: Vary the size of features from high to low with a spike symbol.
size.newToOldMsg: Vary the size of features from new to old.
size.beforeMsg: Emphasize data before a key date.
size.afterMsg: Emphasize data after a key date.

colorSize.highToLowMsg: Vary the color and size of features from high to low.
colorSize.aboveAndBelowMsg: Show data above and below a value like zero or the average.
colorSize.aboveMsg: Emphasize data above a key value like zero or the average.
colorSize.belowMsg: Emphasize data below a key value like zero or the average.
colorSize.newToOldMsg: Vary the color and size of features from new to old.
colorSize.beforeAndAfterMsg: Vary the color and size of data before and after a key date.
colorSize.beforeMsg: Emphasize data before a key date.
colorSize.afterMsg: Emphasize data after a key date.

errors.invalidReferenceSizeStops: The current map scale isn't suitable for a reference size visualization. Therefore, certain modifications can't be made at this scale. Zoom in or choose a different theme.

methodButton.naturalBreaksMsg: Create classes based on the natural grouping of the data.
methodButton.standardDeviationMsg: Create classes above and below the mean using the standard deviation.
methodButton.quantileMsg: Create classes with the same number of features.
methodButton.definedIntervalMsg: Create classes with given interval width.

classify.cannotClassify: Cannot classify using the current color ramp. Change color ramps to classify your data.

regenerate.regenerateTooltip: Determines what data is used to generate the visual range for a given style.

defaultSymbol.showDefaultSymbolClassed: Show features with out of range or no values
defaultSymbol.label: Label

stretchTypeOptionDescriptions.none: Displays values between the potential minimum and maximum.
stretchTypeOptionDescriptions.minimumMaximum: Displays values between the actual minimum and maximum.
stretchTypeOptionDescriptions.percentClip: Cut off percentages of highest and lowest values.
stretchTypeOptionDescriptions.standardDeviation: Displays values between a specified number of standard deviations.

relationshipFocusButton.focusNoneMsg: The legend is a square with no focus on a particular corner.
relationshipFocusButton.focusHighHighMsg: The legend is a diamond, focusing on features with high values for both fields.
relationshipFocusButton.focusHighLowMsg: The legend is a diamond, focusing on features with high values in the first field and low values in the second field.
relationshipFocusButton.focusLowHighMsg: The legend is a diamond, focusing on features with low values in the first and high values in the second field.
relationshipFocusButton.focusLowLowMsg: The legend is a diamond, focusing on features with low values for both fields.

assistFeedback.tellUs: Tell us about your experience with the smart mapping assistant.
assistFeedback.dontShare: Please don't share any personal, confidential, or proprietary information.
assistFeedback.whatChallenges: What challenges did you run into? What would you want to see in the future?
assistFeedback.shareEmail: Share your email address with us so we can contact you regarding your feedback. Your email address will be deleted from our records after 30 days.
